meta_data.title: Sociologically-Informed Neural Networks: A Framework for Predicting Opinion Dynamics
meta_data.abstract: In this paper, we introduce a novel computational framework called Sociologically-Informed Neural Network (SINN) to model and predict opinion dynamics in social networks. Our approach integrates the interpretability of sociological and psychological theories with the data-driven capabilities of neural networks. Through extensive experiments on multiple datasets, we demonstrate that SINN outperforms traditional and contemporary predictive models, making it ideal for applications in social media analytics and marketing strategies. The model bridges the gap between established theoretical knowledge and modern data science approaches, offering both depth and flexibility in understanding the evolution of social opinions.
meta_data.venue: International Conference on Computational Social Science

relate work.comparisons with related methods: Existing opinion dynamics models often lack flexibility, relying on hand-crafted functions. By contrast, SINN incorporates stochastic processes with a deeper learning architecture, overcoming limitations related to stochastic interactions and the incorporation of side information.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: This paper proposes SINN, a novel framework that combines sociological opinion dynamics models with advanced neural network architectures. The approach multi-dimensionally addresses the limitations of existing models and emphasizes the cohesion of theoretical social science and practical machine learning.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To enhance the predictive ability of opinion dynamics modeling by integrating data from social networks with sociological knowledge.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Integrating large-scale data with theoretical models to predict social opinion dynamics, especially accounting for the stochastic nature of interactions.
high_level_summary.method summary: SINN integrates large-scale social media data with opinion dynamics models reformulated into ordinary differential equations (ODEs). It incorporates stochastic processes, side information via NLP techniques, and network structural knowledge.
high_level_summary.conclusion: The SINN framework effectively predicts opinion evolution, demonstrating superior performance over conventional models across various datasets.

Method.description: The SINN framework reformulates traditional opinion dynamics models into differential equations, utilizing neural networks to approximate opinion evolution influenced by social interaction.
Method.problem formultaion: The goal is to predict future opinions of social network users, leveraging historical opinions and side information.
Method.feature processing: Uses BERT for extracting features from social media posts and user profiles.
Method.model: A hybrid neural network integrating features from social media and theoretical models of social interaction.
tasks: Incorporating side data for opinion prediction
Method.theoretical analysis: The integration of opinion dynamics into the differential equation framework allows a theoretical basis for modeling opinion evolutions with high fidelity.
Method.complexity: The deep architecture requires computational resources, but optimally navigates trade-offs between data scale and predictive complexity.
Method.algorithm step: Reformulate opinion dynamics as ODEs; integrate side information; train model; predict future opinions.

Experiments.setup: Conducted experiments with a mixture of synthetic and real-world datasets, emphasizing model robustness across varying conditions.
Experiments.results: SINN outperformed all baseline models across synthetic and real datasets, validating its superiority in capturing complex social interactions.
Experiments.performance: Excellent across both synthetic and real datasets, showcasing robustness in handling variances in opinion dynamics.
Experiments.analysis: Demonstrated the importance of combining sociological theory with data-driven approaches to comprehensively model opinion evolution.

conclusion.summary: The Sociologically-Informed Neural Network (SINN) demonstrates great promise in predicting opinion dynamics with superior accuracy and understanding, blending data and social science effectively.
conclusion.future work: Future work includes integrating opinion mining methodologies for automatic label generation and expanding to include more diverse side information.
